subject: Languages
title: N'Ko: An Alphabet Born in 1949
description: A short lesson to help you apply N'Ko: An Alphabet Born in 1949.

hook.text: A Guinean scholar created a brand-new alphabet in 1949 to prove that African languages deserved their own script.

buildup.text: Solomana KantÃ© was outraged by a claim that African languages couldn't be written. He set out to prove it wrong.

discovery.text: N'Ko script writes Manding languages spoken by tens of millions across West Africa.

twist.text: Despite being designed in the 20th century, N'Ko spread through handwritten books and market signs.

climax.text: N'Ko was added to Unicode in 2006 and now has digital fonts, keyboards, and a Wikipedia.

punchline.text: One man's anger at a colonial insult created an alphabet used by millions.

quiz.question: Why did Solomana KantÃ© create N'Ko?
options: To prove African languages could have their own writing system
